ç­”æ¡ˆ: It depends of what method you want to do. It can be a class to help you build a binary search tree, a structure to help you hold your information and using the linked list method. Nevertheless, no matter what you choose, their process is somewhat the same. 
To delete a node in a binary search tree you have to point in what direction it may be: right or left. When you found the node you want to delete, you just have to declare it null and then that node will be lost in the abyss forever. No take backs.

é¡Œç›®: 
ç­”æ¡ˆ: For a node that is to be deleted there can be four cases.

No nodes below:
Delete current node.

Only left node below:
Delete current node and connect left node to previous node.

Only right node below:
Delete current node and connect right node to previous node.

Both left and right nodes below:
Find the left most node on the sub-tree to the right and replace the current node with the found node, then delete the node that was found.

é¡Œç›®: 
ç­”æ¡ˆ: 1. Heaps have to be complete binary trees, while binary search trees can have unfilled nodes.

2. Binary search trees are sorted with larger values to the right and smaller values to the left, while heaps are not.

3. Heaps allow duplicate values, while binary search trees do not.
output: The 3rd item is not quite correct. Both of them allow duplicate values.
